message_1: Calculate the change in internal energy of a system that releases 350 J of heat to the surroundings and does 200 J of work on its surroundings?
message_2:
To calculate the change in internal energy (ΔU) of a system, we can use the first law of thermodynamics, which states:

ΔU = q + w

where ΔU is the change in internal energy, q is the heat exchanged with the surroundings, and w is the work done on or by the system.

In this case, the system releases 350 J of heat to the surroundings, so q = -350 J (negative because heat is released). The system also does 200 J of work on its surroundings, so w = -200 J (negative because work is done on the surroundings).

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔU = (-350 J) + (-200 J)

ΔU = -550 J

The change in internal energy of the system is -550 J.
